source: using PyPlot

# Generate some data
n = 1000

d = 10
k = 4
X = randn(n, d)
w_true = [-5, 17, 5, 0, 0, -7, 5, 0, 0, 0.1]
y = X*w_true + .1*randn(n);
d) Code the proximal gradient method for the Sparse Least Squares Problem.

function prox_sls(w)
    m=countnz(w)
    dum=copy(w)
    if(m<=4)
        return w
    else
        for j =1:length(w)-4
            i = ind2sub(size(Array(dum)), indmin(abs(Array(dum))))
            f(x) = x == dum[i[1]]
            k=find(f,w)
            w[k[1]]=0.0
            deleteat!(dum,i[1])
        end
        return w
    end
end

function proxgrad_quad_sls(X, y; maxiters = 10, stepsize = 1, w = zeros(size(X,2)))
    objval = Float64[]
    iterations =Int64[]
    for i=1:maxiters
        # gradient step
        g = 2*X'*(X*w-y) # compute quadratic gradient
        w = w - stepsize*g
        # prox step
        w = prox_sls(w)
        # record objective value
        push!(objval, norm(X*w-y)^2)
        push!(iterations, i)
    end
    return w, objval, iterations
end
s=10*randn(10)
 w, obj, iterations = proxgrad_quad_sls(X, y, maxiters = 100, stepsize = 0.000075, w=s)
print(w)
semilogy(iterations, obj,".")
e) Run the algorithm starting at multiple locations and create a histogram of the objective value. Use 100 iterations for each run.

histo=Float64[]

for l=1:50
    p=randn(10)
    w, obj, iterations = proxgrad_quad_sls(X, y, maxiters = 100, stepsize = 0.000075, w=p*10)
    push!(histo,obj[100])
    semilogy(iterations, obj,".")

end
The above plot shows the convergence with each iteration and the below plot is a histogram of the objective values

source: plt[:hist](histo) #histogram of objective values
f) Run LASSO regression using the proximal gradient method on this problem. You may use the code from the demo in class.

function prox_l1(x::Number, alpha=1)
    if x > alpha
        return x-alpha
    elseif x < -alpha
        return x + alpha
    else
        return 0
    end
end
function prox_l1(x::AbstractArray, alpha=1)
    return reshape(Float64[prox_l1(xi, alpha) for xi in x], size(x))
end
# proximal gradient method for quadratic loss and l1 regularizer
function proxgrad_quad_l1(X, y; maxiters = 20, stepsize = 1, λ = 1, w = zeros(size(X,2)))
    objval = Float64[]
    
    for i=1:maxiters
        # gradient step
        
        g = 2X'*(X*w-y) # compute quadratic gradient
        w = w - stepsize*g
        
        # prox step
        w = prox_l1(w, stepsize*λ)
        # record objective value
        push!(objval, norm(X*w-y)^2 + norm(w,1))
        
    end
    return w, objval, iterations
end
g) Does LASSO converge to the same place starting from different places?

histo=Float64[]
for i=1:10
    w, obj, iterations =proxgrad_quad_l1(X,y,maxiters=100,stepsize=0.00005,w=10*randn(10))
    print(w,"\n")
    
end
We can see from the above values of w that indeed, yes, the lasso does seem to converge even when it starts from different places
h) Compare the SLS solution to the LASSO solution.

p=randn(10)*10
w, obj, iterations = proxgrad_quad_sls(X, y, maxiters = 100, stepsize = 0.000075, w=p)
print("For SLS: w is ",w,"\n","Objective value: ", obj[100], "\n")
w, obj, iterations =proxgrad_quad_l1(X,y,maxiters=100,stepsize=0.00005,w=p)
print("For LASSO: w is ",w,"\n","Objective value: ",obj[100], "\n")
We can see from the above output we can see that the SLS solution is more sparse. However the LASSO achieves a much better objective value. Checking reliability:

histo=Float64[]
print("For the SLS problem (objective values) :","\n")
for l=1:10
    p=randn(10)
    w, obj, iterations = proxgrad_quad_sls(X, y, maxiters = 100, stepsize = 0.000075, w=p*10)
    print(obj[100],"\n")
end
print("\n","For the LASSO problem (objective values) :","\n")
histo=Float64[]
for i=1:10
    w, obj, iterations =proxgrad_quad_l1(X,y,maxiters=100,stepsize=0.00005,w=10*randn(10))
    print(obj[100],"\n")
    
end
Hence as the LASSO consistently gives lower objective values than the SLS we can consider it to be more reliable.
b) Code the stochastic proximal gradient method for the Sparse Least Squares problem.

function stochproxgrad_quad_sls(X, y; maxiters = 10, stepsize = 1, w = zeros(size(X,2)))
    objval = Float64[]
    iterations =Int64[]
    for i=1:maxiters
        # gradient step
        j=rand(1:1000)
        g = 2*1000*(((X[j,:])'*w-y[j])[1])*X[j,:]# compute quadratic gradient
        w = w - stepsize*g
        w = prox_sls(vec(w))
        # record objective value
        push!(objval, norm(X*w-y)^2)
        push!(iterations, i)
    end
    return w, objval, iterations
end
c) Using the same data as in problem 2, plot the objective value as a function of the number of iterations.

histo=Float64[]
w, obj, iterations= stochproxgrad_quad_sls(X,y, maxiters=1000,stepsize=0.00001,w=s)
push!(histo,norm(X*w-y)^2)
semilogy(iterations, obj,".")
d) How long does the stochastic proximal gradient method take compared to the standard proximal gradient method?

The stochastic proximal gradient method takes a lot more iterations to converge. While the standard proximal gradient method starts to converge to the final objective value at the 30th iteration, the stochastic proximal gradient method only starts to converge at the 250th iteration.

It takes longer time as well, the standard proximal gradient only takes 3.12 seconds to run for 200 different starting values, whereas the stochastic proximal gradient takes 8.24 seconds to run for 200 different starting values. This may be due to the larger number of iterations needed to make it converge.
e) Run the algorithm starting at multiple locations and create a histogram of the objective value. What do you observe?

histo=Float64[]
 for i=1:50
    w, obj, iterations= stochproxgrad_quad_sls(X,y, maxiters=1000,stepsize=0.00001,w=5*randn(10))
    push!(histo,norm(X*w-y)^2)
    semilogy(iterations, obj,".")
end

The above plot shows the convergence of the objective value as the program is run for multiple different starting values. In the plot below we see the histogram for the same, it can be seen that there are two different minimas that the function is converging to. This may be because it is not convex, hence some of the iterations are stopping at a local minima and not reaching the global minima.

source: plt[:hist](histo,50)
#Q4 part c

function proxsubgrad(maxiters=10, stepsize=1, w=0.0)
    allw=Float64[] 
    objval=Float64[]
    iterations=Int64[]
    for i=1:maxiters
        if w!=0.0
            g=sign(w)
        else
            g=-2*rand()+1
        end
        w=(w-stepsize*g)/3
        
        push!(allw,w)
        push!(objval, abs(0-1*w)+(w^2))
        push!(iterations,i)
    end
    return allw, objval, iterations
end

allw, objval, iterations=proxsubgrad(100, 1)
plot(iterations,allw)
In this case the iterates do not seem to be converging.
#Q4 part d

#Running with a different value of x and a different step size
allw, objval, iterations=proxsubgrad(100, 0.3, rand()*4)
plot(iterations,allw)
With different step sizes and different starting points it is observed that, while initially there is a change in the value of w, eventually it seems to just oscillate about the minima 0.

source:
#Running with decreasing step size
function proxsubgrad(maxiters=10, stepsize=1, w=0.0)
    allw=Float64[] 
    objval=Float64[]
    iterations=Int64[]
    for i=1:maxiters
        if w!=0.0
            g=sign(w)
        else
            g=-2*rand()+1
        end
        w=(w-stepsize*(1/i)*g)/3
        
        push!(allw,w)
        push!(objval, abs(0-1*w)+(w^2))
        push!(iterations,i)
    end
    return allw, objval, iterations
end

allw, objval, iterations=proxsubgrad(100, 1, rand())

semilogy(iterations,objval,".")
plot(iterations,allw)
By using a decreasing step size, convergence is reached more efficiently and the oscillations reduce in magnitude.
